item.title: Why Do People Stop Taking Their Meds? Cost Is Just One Reason
item.description: September 8, 2017 - The latest NPR-Truven Health Analytics poll finds that one-third of people say they're stopped taking a prescription drug without telling their doctor. And that could be putting their health at risk.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 8, 2017 - The latest NPR-Truven Health Analytics poll finds that one-third of people say they're stopped taking a prescription drug without telling their doctor. And that could be putting their health at risk. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/08/549414152/why-do-people-stop-taking-their-meds-cost-is-just-one-reason

item.title: The Powerful Pull Of Opioids Leaves Many 'Missing' From U.S. Workforce
item.description: September 8, 2017 - Opioid addiction affects people's work lives more than alcohol or other drugs, and those who struggle with it tell strikingly similar tales of deepening alienation from their careers.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 8, 2017 - Opioid addiction affects people's work lives more than alcohol or other drugs, and those who struggle with it tell strikingly similar tales of deepening alienation from their careers. http://www.npr.org/2017/09/08/548867893/the-powerful-pull-of-opioids-leaves-many-missing-from-u-s-workforce

item.title: Governors Sound Off On How To Fix Health Insurance
item.description: September 7, 2017 - Senators holding hearings this week are looking for quick tweaks that will stabilize the insurance markets and make policies cheaper. Some governors want more federal money and more flexibility.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - Senators holding hearings this week are looking for quick tweaks that will stabilize the insurance markets and make policies cheaper. Some governors want more federal money and more flexibility. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/07/549193137/governors-sound-off-on-how-to-fix-health-insurance

item.title: Deadly Bird Flu In China Evolves, Spreads To New Regions
item.description: September 7, 2017 - In the 2017 outbreak, the Chinese government reported 759 cases of the H7N9 avian flu, with 281 deaths. By comparison, in 2016 there were 123 cases.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - In the 2017 outbreak, the Chinese government reported 759 cases of the H7N9 avian flu, with 281 deaths. By comparison, in 2016 there were 123 cases. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/09/07/549069924/deadly-bird-flu-in-china-evolves-spreads-to-new-regions

item.title: Governors Provide Plans To Fix Health Insurance Markets
item.description: September 7, 2017 - Several governors were in Washington, D.C., to testify before the Senate health committee about their bipartisan plan to shore up the health insurance marketplace. NPR's Robert Siegel talks to Republican Gov. Gary Herbert of Utah and Democratic Gov. John Hickenlooper of Colorado.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - Several governors were in Washington, D.C., to testify before the Senate health committee about their bipartisan plan to shore up the health insurance marketplace. NPR's Robert Siegel talks to Republican Gov. Gary Herbert of Utah and Democratic Gov. John Hickenlooper of Colorado. http://www.npr.org/2017/09/07/549250049/governors-provide-plans-to-fix-health-insurance-markets

item.title: A Pioneer Of Food Activism Steps Down, Looks Back
item.description: September 7, 2017 - Michael Jacobson invented a new style of food activism. For four decades, he led the fight against "junk food." He's now stepping down as president of the Center for Science in the Public Interest.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - Michael Jacobson invented a new style of food activism. For four decades, he led the fight against "junk food." He's now stepping down as president of the Center for Science in the Public Interest. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/09/07/548715416/a-pioneer-of-food-activism-steps-down-looks-back

item.title: A Toilet Is The Star Of India's Hit Rom-Com
item.description: September 7, 2017 - She loves him. He loves her. But she loves indoor toilets even more. And he is not a fan. Can they find happiness? The plot of Toilet: A Love Story addresses a very real issue in rural India.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - She loves him. He loves her. But she loves indoor toilets even more. And he is not a fan. Can they find happiness? The plot of Toilet: A Love Story addresses a very real issue in rural India. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/09/07/547607355/-no-toilet-no-love

item.title: Fashion Gets Real
item.description:
September 7, 2017 - Is a step away from size 0 models PR, or real reform?

item.title: Opioid Crisis Looms Over Job Market, Worrying Employers And Economists
item.description: September 7, 2017 - Companies across the U.S. say it's getting harder to find applicants and keep workers once they've been hired. Economists from the Federal Reserve to Wall Street say opioid addiction may be a factor.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 7, 2017 - Companies across the U.S. say it's getting harder to find applicants and keep workers once they've been hired. Economists from the Federal Reserve to Wall Street say opioid addiction may be a factor. http://www.npr.org/2017/09/07/545602212/opioid-crisis-looms-over-job-market-worrying-employers-and-economists

item.title: Will Congress Continue Health Care For 9 Million Children?
item.description: September 6, 2017 - The popular Children's Health Insurance Program is up for renewal Sept. 30. Policy analysts say it's unclear whether a deeply divided Congress facing major deadlines will get the job done.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 6, 2017 - The popular Children's Health Insurance Program is up for renewal Sept. 30. Policy analysts say it's unclear whether a deeply divided Congress facing major deadlines will get the job done. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/06/548951827/congress-weighs-future-of-children-s-health-insurance

item.title: When It Comes To Romantic Attraction, Real Life Beats Questionnaires
item.description: September 6, 2017 - Questionnaires of the sort used by dating apps don't come close to predicting initial attraction compared with meeting someone in real life, a study finds. The ineffable mystery of romance remains.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 6, 2017 - Questionnaires of the sort used by dating apps don't come close to predicting initial attraction compared with meeting someone in real life, a study finds. The ineffable mystery of romance remains. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/06/548645037/when-it-comes-to-romantic-attraction-real-life-beats-questionnaires

item.title: 'I Needed Someone To See Me': One Refugee's Story Of Recovery
item.description: September 6, 2017 - For Ahmad Chahabi, reaching the safety of Germany was only the first step. Today he's drawing from his own experience to help the newly arrived.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 6, 2017 - For Ahmad Chahabi, reaching the safety of Germany was only the first step. Today he's drawing from his own experience to help the newly arrived. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/09/06/548624782/the-counselor-whos-walked-many-miles-in-a-refugees-shoes

item.title: Houston Methadone Clinics Reopen After Harvey's Flooding
item.description: September 6, 2017 - Hurricane Harvey disrupted treatment for people addicted to opioids. Many need to get connected to a specialty clinic that can provide medication-assisted treatment.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 6, 2017 - Hurricane Harvey disrupted treatment for people addicted to opioids. Many need to get connected to a specialty clinic that can provide medication-assisted treatment. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/06/548819207/houston-methadone-clinics-reopen-after-harveys-flooding

item.title: Chastened Lawmakers Aim For Small, Bipartisan Health Care Victories
item.description:
September 5, 2017 - Senate Republicans and Democrats are trying something new on health care. It's called cooperation.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/05/548676514/chastened-lawmakers-aim-for-small-bipartisan-health-care-victories

item.title: Whatever Happened To ... The Mission To Get Rid Of Rwanda's Dirt Floors?
item.description: September 5, 2017 - A small project started in 2014 to replace dirt floors, which can make people sick, with sealed earthen floors. Demand has only grown — but not exactly in the way the CEO had imagined.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 5, 2017 - A small project started in 2014 to replace dirt floors, which can make people sick, with sealed earthen floors. Demand has only grown — but not exactly in the way the CEO had imagined. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/09/05/547407906/whatever-happened-to-the-mission-to-get-rid-of-rwanda-s-dirt-floors
